section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with a game, and introduce vocabulary (circle, square).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How do the people in the story feel?
Read for enjoyment, pointing out how the people feel as well as the shapes around them.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts; Use perception to guide movement through space and interactions with objects and people.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Have children pair shapes with real-world objects that are the same shape.
Guide children to recognize similarities in objects of the same shape.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What book did you choose? Why did you choose that one?
What music do you like to dance to?
What can you make with Pattern Blocks?
Can you write about your favorite song? Why do you like it?
What can you draw that is made of shapes?
What letter does song start with? How do you make that letter?
What shapes are the blocks you are using?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder play with others and introduce vocabulary (invite, sphere).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Every Little Thing.
Read closely to notice how to invite someone to play and to review shapes.
Offer an extended play opportunity, during which children practice inviting a friend to play.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square, rectangle, triangle—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles; Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to invite a partner to work together to draw.
Challenge children to work with partners and draw as many items as possible that are a basic shape such as a triangle, circle, or square.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What shapes do you see in that book?
Show how you can invite a new friend to play with you.
Look at these pieces. Which pieces are circles and which pieces are squares?
Write a note inviting a friend to play.
How can you make a circle? How can you make a square?
What letter does music start with? What letter does square start with? Can you write those letters?
Which shaped block is easiest to build with? Why?

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to review patterns, engage children with a song, and introduce the vocabulary (mistake, cube).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, How does the music change how the people in the book feel?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to recognize patterns in the rhymes.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns, including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Share and celebrate written products.
Produce rhyming words.
Engage in conversations with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Create patterns using two colors of Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to identify a mistake made in the pattern.
Invite children to fix the mistake.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Are there any rhyming words in your book? How do you know?
Can you pretend to play music on an imaginary instrument?
Can you draw different shapes? Which shapes?
Can you write a story that has rhymes in it?
How can you use shapes to draw a picture?
I hear sh at the beginning of shapes. S and h together make the sh sound. Can you trace or write the letters s and h?
Do you see square blocks? Do you remember the name for an object that is made of six sides that are all squares?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Every Little Thing by Cedella Marley, illustrated by Vanessa Brantley-Newton. Text copyright © 2012 by Cedella Marley. Illustrations copyright © 2012 by Vanessa Brantley-Newton. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Chronicle Books LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: Old MacDonald’s Farm

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to play a pattern game, notice rhyme in song, and introduce vocabulary words (farm, goats).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts Old MacDonald’s Farm and Every Little Thing.
Read interactively and connect to patterns by showing how parts of the song repeat with each animal.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns, including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.

Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle; Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Initiate play and join a group in play.
Produce rhyming words.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to invite friends to work together.
Have children create ABAB and AABB patterns using simple shapes.
Challenge partners to continue the patterns started.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Are there any farm animals in your book?
Pretend to be one of the animals from Old MacDonald’s farm. What do you sound like?
How can you make a farm animal out of shapes?
Can you write a song or story with rhymes in it?
Draw a picture that has a pattern in it.
Which was your favorite animal sound? What letter sounds do you hear in it?
Build towers in a pattern of tall, short, tall, short.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Every Little Thing by Cedella Marley, illustrated by Vanessa Brantley-Newton. Text copyright © 2012 by Cedella Marley. Illustrations copyright © 2012 by Vanessa Brantley-Newton. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Chronicle Books LLC.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to dance, sing, and go on a shape count.
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, What part of the song in the book reminds you of your life?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement as well as a focus on shapes.
Check understanding, differentiating as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns, including A, B, A, B; AA, BB, AA, BB; and ABC, ABC.

Create, compose, decompose, and talk about common two-dimensional shapes, including circle, square, rectangle, and triangle; Recognize, name, and describe common two-dimensional shapes—circle, square—using words related to number of sides, length of sides, and number of points or angles.
Identify emotions in self.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.
Produce rhyming words.
Share and celebrate written products.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Share a time that music and dance made you feel happy.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s responses to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through music and dance?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How do the people or animals in your book share how they feel?
Can you make up a dance to express yourself? What does your dance show?
Create a pattern of shapes. What shape comes next?
Write a song about yourself and how you feel.
Can you create artwork using your favorite shape?
What sound do you hear in the beginning of the word pattern? What letter makes that sound?
What is the biggest shape you can build?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Name common shapes.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Name common shapes.
Create shapes.
Develop working memory to solve problems and accomplish goals.
Increasingly interact and communicate with peers to initiate pretend play scenarios that share a common plan and goal.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Use a variety of art materials and activities for sensory experience and exploration.
Name common shapes.
Recognize and create patterns.
Show competence initiating social interactions.
Recognize rhyming words.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Name common shapes.
Create shapes.
Recognize and create patterns.
Show competence initiating social interactions.
Recognize rhyming words.
Name common shapes.
Create shapes.
Recognize and create patterns.
Can communicate basic emotions/feelings.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Recognize rhyming words.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
